April 9, 2000: Fiction
THE BRETHREN, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $27.95.) Three former judges,
doing time at a federal prison in Florida, concoct a mail scam that goes awry.
HARRY POTTER AND THE CHAMBER OF SECRETS, by J. K. Rowling.
(Levine/Scholastic, $17.95.) A British boy finds trouble when he returns to a
witchcraft school.
CAROLINA MOON, by Nora Roberts. (Putnam, $24.95.) A woman returns to the
town where she grew up and where her best friend was murdered.
HARRY POTTER AND THE PRISONER OF AZKABAN, by J. K. Rowling.
(Levine/Scholastic, $19.95.) A British boy's life at a school for witchcraft is
threatened.
DAUGHTER OF FORTUNE, by Isabel Allende. (HarperCollins, $26.) A young
woman joins the 1849 gold rush.
HARRY POTTER AND THE SORCERER'S STONE, by J. K. Rowling.
(Levine/Scholastic, $16.95.) A British boy finds his fortune attending a school for
witchcraft.
BRIDGET JONES: The Edge of Reason, by Helen Fielding. (Viking, $24.95.)
Another year in the life of a single woman in London.
GAP CREEK, by Robert Morgan. (Algonquin, $22.95.) The fortunes of a struggling
young couple in Appalachia.
DAY OF RECKONING, by Jack Higgins. (Putnam, $25.95.) The head of a secret
White House department sets out to destroy an international crime boss.
WHERE YOU BELONG, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. (Doubleday, $24.95.) A
brokenhearted photojournalist decides to cover celebrities instead of wars.
BEOWULF, translated by Seamus Heaney. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $25.) A new
rendering of the Anglo-Saxon epic by a Nobel Prize-winning Irish poet.
THE LION'S GAME, by Nelson DeMille. (Warner, $26.95.) A former New York
homicide detective helps federal agents as they pursue a Libyan terrorist.
TOUGH COOKIE, by Diane Mott Davidson. (Bantam, $23.95.) A chef investigates
the suspicious death of her ex-boyfriend, chairman of the Colorado parole board.
DEEP SOUTH, by Nevada Barr. (Putnam, $23.95.) The national park ranger Anna
Pigeon tries to solve a mystery: who killed a teenage girl in the Mississippi woods?
MOMENT OF TRUTH, by Lisa Scottoline. (HarperCollins, $25.) A lawyer finds
herself defending an innocent man, accused of murder, who insists he is guilty.
April 9, 2000
Non-Fiction
TUESDAYS WITH MORRIE, by Mitch Albom. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The author
tells of his weekly visits to his old college mentor, who was near death's door.
THE BODYGUARD'S STORY, by Trevor Rees-Jones with Moira Johnston.
(Warner, $25.95.) The bodyguard who accompanied Diana, Princess of Wales, on
the night she died describes the car crash and its aftermath.
THE ROCK SAYS . . ., by the Rock with Joe Layden. (ReganBooks/HarperCollins,
$26.) A memoir by a professional wrestler.
THE DEATH OF INNOCENCE, by John and Patsy Ramsey. (Thoma/Thomas
Nelson, $24.99.) The parents of JonBenet Ramsey give their side of the story.
THE MILLIONAIRE MIND, by Thomas J. Stanley. (Andrews McMeel, $26.95.) An
analysis of the people who make up America's financial elite.
A HEARTBREAKING WORK OF STAGGERING GENIUS, by Dave Eggers.
(Simon & Schuster, $23.) A young man's account of raising his 8-year-old brother
after their parents died just weeks apart.
THE CASE AGAINST HILLARY CLINTON, by Peggy Noonan. (ReganBooks/
HarperCollins, $24.) A former Reagan speechwriter calls the first lady to account.
'TIS, by Frank McCourt. (Scribner, $26.) An Irish immigrant gets used to life in
America: the second volume of a memoir.
THE GREATEST GENERATION, by Tom Brokaw. (Random House, $24.95.) The
lives of men and women who came of age during the Depression and World War
II.
HAVE A NICE DAY! by Mick Foley. (ReganBooks/ HarperCollins, $25.) The
autobiography of a professional wrestler known as Mankind.
SHRUB, by Molly Ivins and Lou Dubose. (Random House, $19.95.) A critical
account of the career of Gov. George W. Bush of Texas.
THE ART OF HAPPINESS, by the Dalai Lama and Howard C. Cutler. (Riverhead,
$22.95.) What Buddhism and common sense tell us about everyday problems.
THE TIPPING POINT, by Malcolm Gladwell. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) A journalist's
study of social epidemics, otherwise known as fads.
THE GREATEST GENERATION SPEAKS, by Tom Brokaw. (Random House,
$19.95.) What the people who fought in World War II confided in letters to the
author.
PEANUTS: A Golden Celebration, by Charles M. Schulz; edited by David Larkin.
